clinical_study.brief_title: Mechanisms for Dyspnea on Exertion in Children With Obesity and Asthma
clinical_study.official_title: Mechanisms for Dyspnea on Exertion in Children With Obesity and Asthma

brief_summary.textblock: The overall objective of this study is to delineate specific contributions of obesity-related respiratory limitations vs. asthma-related bronchoconstriction in children with obesity and asthma.

detailed_description.textblock:
Children who suffer from obesity and asthma report poor asthma control and high use of rescue medications primarily due to increased dyspnea on exertion (DOE). Obesity alters breathing mechanics and increases respiratory limitations during exercise, which can provoke DOE. Unfortunately the role of obesity in causing DOE is underappreciated during diagnosis/management of DOE in asthmatic children with obesity.
For example, children with obesity and asthma experience asthma-related respiratory limitations such as bronchoconstriction, which would respond to "asthma medications", but they also experience obesity-related respiratory limitations, which would not respond to "asthma medications", or they could suffer from both. Considering the alarming reports of poor symptom control and high DOE in children with obesity and asthma, there is a critical need to identify the separate contributions of obesity-related vs. asthma-related mechanisms in development of DOE so we can better diagnose/manage this unique patient population. Therefore, the overall objective of this study is to delineate specific contributions of obesity-related respiratory limitations vs. asthma-related bronchoconstriction in children with obesity and asthma.
We will use an exercise-testing model to concurrently assess obesity-related respiratory limitations and asthma-related bronchoconstriction in 9-12-year-old asthmatic children with and without obesity. We will phenotype participants based on their bronchoconstriction response to exercise: No bronchoconstriction (i.e., <10% fall in forced expiratory volume in 1s [FEV1]) and Yes bronchoconstriction (i.e., ≥10% fall in FEV1). Since short-acting bronchodilators like albuterol are a standard-of-care pre-exercise prescription to prevent asthma-related bronchoconstriction, we will also determine the extent to which albuterol is effective in reducing DOE and asthma-related bronchoconstriction in asthmatic children with and without obesity.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: 2x2 design. 2 groups (between factor): Obese and nonobese 2 repeated measures (within factor): Albuterol and no albuterol

secondary_outcome.description: Rating of perceived breathlessness during exercise

arm_group.description: Children will undergo a moderate intensity exercise session under two conditions: without pretreatment with albuterol with pretreatment with albuterol

intervention.description: 2 puffs of albuterol (90mcg per actuation) will be administered 15min before the exercise test
In this condition, the participants will be seated for 15min before the exercise test

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- 9 - 12-year-old
- early puberty (i.e., Tanner stage <4)
- physician diagnosed asthma and regular use of asthma controller therapy (i.e., inhaled corticosteroids, leukotriene receptor antagonists, long acting beta agonists, etc) for the past 8 weeks
We will study two groups of asthmatic children:
1. without obesity (BMI 16th-65th percentile)
2. with overweight/obesity (BMI ≥85th percentile)
Exclusion Criteria:
- Oral steroids in past 3 weeks
- ICU admission or intubation in past 5 years
- FEV1 less than 50% predicted
- cardiovascular, renal or metabolic disease
- significant mental illness
- uncontrolled sleep disorder
- unable to exercise on a stationary bike
